awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Combining Models and Experiment for Quantitative Characterization of Electrocatalytic Carbon Dioxide Reduction on Doped Ceria
awd_abstract_narration:
The project investigates a high-temperature electrochemical approach for converting the carbon in carbon dioxide (CO2) gas to higher value carbon-containing products such as hydrocarbon fuels, thereby serving as a critical component in eventual closed carbon-cycle processes for renewable energy generation.  Specifically, the project will investigate the reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide (CO) on high-temperature cerium oxide based electrodes utilizing a combination of experimental techniques, theoretical models, and statistical methods to distinguish between various reaction mechanisms that have been proposed but remain unverified.  The resulting understanding will provide guidance for designing solid oxide electrodes with improved efficiency and durability.

Thin-film test cells with ceria working electrodes on yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) electrolytes will be fabricated, exposed to CO and CO2-containing gases and polarized at high temperature.  The potential gradient in the film caused by the polarization yields a gradient in the surface potential as a function of distance from the current collector. These changes in surface potential - a quantity closely related to the concentrations of active intermediates on the ceria surface - will be measured, during cell operation, with sub-100 nm lateral resolution utilizing in-operando high-temperature scanning surface potential microscopy (HT-SSPM). These data, along with full-cell electrochemical impedance spectroscopy data (EIS), will be collected for a matrix of different experimental conditions including changes in gas composition, temperature, applied cell potential, dopant concentration, and thermal aging.  Electrocatalytic phase-field modeling (EPFM), which couples mechanistic models of the catalytic reaction with the material behavior of the ceria electrode, will be quantitatively calibrated to the entire experimental dataset using Bayesian model-based analysis (BMA). Models generated and conclusions drawn during the course of this project will be useful for further development of high-temperature, mixed ionic-electronic conducting catalysts. The unique coupling of state-of-the-art in-operando HT-SSPM and EPFM methods is made possible by Bayesian calibration, which quantitatively links large experimental datasets and complex models, leading to estimates of model parameters (with uncertainty quantification) along with assessments of the model fitness in light of the data.  BMA also affords the opportunity to incorporate existing measurements or calculations (including quantum calculations) of key parameters in the analysis.  In addition to the technical elements, the project will include a lab activity for high school physics students that will be developed in the researchers' local communities and publicized nationally.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This award advanced the use of high temperature scanning surface potential microscopy (HT-SSPM) as a real-time method for probing activity of electrocatalysts with sub-100 nm resolution at elevated temperatures above 500?C. A series of ceria-based electrocatalyst surfaces were measured using this method to determine the evolution of potential with doping. Additionally, related studies involving oxygen vacancy concentrations profiles, 3D reconstruction of vacancy filaments, and vacancy-mediated resistance changes in thin films were completed and published.

The real-time operando scan probes generated electrocatalystic potential profiles under reactive environments and temperatures, then given collaborators (Mebane Group; WVU) to calibrate predictive computational models of electroactive surfaces. This experimental data series of CeO2 (ceria) and gadolinia-doped ceria (GDC) represented one of the first direct connections to electroactive phase field models.

Figure 1 shows the potential profiles of a) pure ceria, b) GDC10, c) GDC20, and d) GDC30 surfaces. In the reactive gas mixture, the surfaces starkly contrasting surface potentials, as shown by the red dotted boxes indicating the active region. Pure ceria, with limited electronic conductivity and available vacancies, displays rather large potential variations extending from the interface (Fig 1a). In contrast, as gadolinia (Gd2O3) doping increases from GDC10 (Fig. 1b) to GDC20 (Fig. 2c), the potential perturbations greatly reduce, as doping generates more vacancies which serve as charge carriers. GDC30 appears to yield higher potential perturbations, however these profiles are attributed to catalytically inactive ?frozen? vacancy clusters which occur at high doping concentrations.

Other studies were enabled by the real-time high temperature probes, including observing how UV-irradiation occurring during common deposition techniques generates different oxygen-vacancies across the depths of model oxides such as SrTiO3. Figure 2 shows topography (Fig. 2a; top) and the potential profile for the UV irradiated (center) and the non-irradiated samples (bottom). Analysis of the surface potentials yields the local carrier concentration (Fig. 2b), which appear comparable between samples along the surface. Irradiated samples display minimal depth dependence while the non-irradiated sample displays a sharp decrease in the first few microns in depth, thus confirming the effects of low pressure annealing with UV-irradiation.

The award also supported development of related scan probe techniques. Superior resistance change uniformity in HfO2 films was realized by embedding highly ordered metal nanoparticles (Figure 3). To observe the morphological evolution of conductive filament paths comprising vacancies, 3D conductive probe nanotomography was employed, whereas a conductive diamond probe first "scraped" a layer, then scanned across the fresh surface to observe local current variations. Combined with cross-sectional electron spectroscopy, correlations between metal nanoparticles and surrounding oxide matrices were made with overall switching performance (Figures 4).

Our group developed a rotation of three nanomaterials modules for the Summer ENGingeering Institute (SENGI) for high school students run here at UMass-Amherst that will now be run each summer run in the summer pre-/post- pandemic. It involved similar probe concepts used in nanocharacterization, but at a more ?hands on? size scale.

Electroactive oxides such as ceria are used in a myriad of electrochemical and electronic applications ranging from fuel cells to memristors. Advancing real-time experimental probes and analytic models will drive the understanding how localized vacancy-driven processes impact overall transport and performance, thus disrupting the empirical measure-model cycle that plagues materials design. The results shown highlight pathways towards direct experimental evidence for spatially-resolved vacancy-mediated processes impacting these important applications.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Stephen Nonnenmann

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1: The HT-SSPM profiles in CO2 environments for a) pure ceria, b) GDC10, c) GDC20, and d) GDC30 surfaces. The black dotted line indicates the interface with the current collector. The red box denotes the active regions along each surface.
    S.S. Nonnenmann
    Copyrighted
    Stephen Nonnenmann
    HT-SSPM of Pure CeO2 and GDC
  • Figure 2: a) The topography (top) and surface potential images of UV-irradiated (mid) and non-irradiated (bottom) SrTiO3. b) The depth profile in the substrate of the local vacancy concentration as calculated from the potential profiles.
    S.S. Nonnenmann
    Creative Commons
    Stephen Nonnenmann
    Potential Profiles of UV-irradiated and non-irradiated SrTiO3
  • Figure 3: Illustration of the template-directed device fabrication approach. b, The cross-sectional schematic of the nanoisland embedded HfO2 RRAM devices. c, SEM image of the ultrathin AAO template after transferring on the substrate. Reused with permission: Wiley #5438310141683
    S.S. Nonnenmann
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Stephen Nonnenmann
    Nanoisland embedded thin films
  • Figure 4: a. top view of 3D construction. b. cross-section shows filaments extending from Pt nanoparticles. Three individual filaments can be observed. c. top view of the filament with respect to particle position and d) 3D reconstruction. Reproduced with permission (Wiley#5438310141683)
    S.S. Nonnenmann
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Stephen Nonnenmann
    3D Nanotomography of vacancy filaments
